iquids stored in atmospheric tanks which are kept  below their normal boiling point without benefit of chilling or refrigeration 40 CFR 1910.119(a)(1)(ii)(B) 

All elements required by USEPA 40 CFR 68 Subpart C (Program 2) are included in the RMP binder identified by their specific requirement.

 
§68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response policies are presented in RMP as required.

§68.155(b) Stationary Source and Substance Handled

The largest storage tank at the facility, 300-1, has a nominal storage capacity of 1,100,000 gallons of toluene 2, 4 diisocyanate.  There are also two (2) smaller volume tanks, 120-2 and 80-2 at the facility for this product service having nominal storage volumes of 170,000 gallons and 280,000 gallons respectively.  

In addition to the stationary sources, there are drumming and rail car operations occurring at the site that has the potential to contain up to 5,800 (55 gal) drums and at minimum one (1) full rail car of TDI.  For maximum inventory calculations, five (5) rail cars are assumed to be staged onsite.  

68.155(c) Off-Site Consequences Analysis

The facility is required to complete one (1) worst-case scenario per hazardous substance handled.  This revision has eliminated all but one chemical that triggers this requirement, toluene 2, 4 diisocyanate.  This first step in developing a RMP is to conduct a Hazard Assessment as described in 40 CFR 68 Subpart B.  The hazard assessment includes the following:

Worst-case release scenario
Alternative release scenario
Off-site population impacts
Off-site environments impacts
Five year accident history

Currently the facility triggers the RMP reporting rule for Program 2 for the on-site storage and drumming of toluene 2, 4 diisocyanate.  There is at any one time, approximately 21,300,000 lbs of toluene 2, 4 diisocyanate at the site, primarily in three (3) above ground fixed roof storage tanks.  The following table p

he vessel or piping containing the largest quantity of the chemical taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity
The entire content of the vessel is released resulting in a vapor cloud explosion at ground level
Passive mitigation systems are considered is system is capable of withstanding the release event and function as intended
Ambient relative humidity is 50%
Ambient temperature is 77o F
Wind speed is 1.5 meters per second at 10 meters above the ground
The atmospheric stability is Class F (very light wind, late night, and partial cloud cover)

40 CFR 68.22 requires the selection of either a rural or an urban setting for the facility.  Urban topography is defined as having many obstacles in the immediate area (obstacles include trees and buildings).  Rural topography means there are no buildings in the immediate area and the terrain is generally flat and unobstructed.  An urban setting was selected for the facility due to its residential and industrial surroundings. 

TDI Storage and Drumming Process

The worst-case release scenario for toluene-2,4 diisocyanate will be a tank failure of 300-1.  This will result in a release of approximately 11,500,000 pounds of TDI.  Modelling via RMP*Comp¿ results indicate an endpoint distance of 0.3 miles from the facility.  According to Landview 6, there are 365 persons, residences, public recreation areas, and major commercial or industrial areas within the endpoint distance. The only environmental receptor identified within the hazard endpoint is the Mississippi River.  
 
Alternative Release Scenario

40 CFR 68.28 requires the owner or operator of RMP Program 2 facility to identify and analyze at least one (1) alternative release scenario to represent all flammable substances held in covered processes.  An alternative release scenario must be more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and must reach an endpoint off-site unless no such scenario exists.  Passive and active mitigation syst

resents OCA results for the facility.  


§68.155(c) OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Introduction

Facilities that store regulated chemicals in excess of threshold quantities as defined in 40 CFR 68.130 are required to develop a Risk Management Plan (RMP) as mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The first step in developing an RMP is to conduct a Hazard Assessment as described in 40 CFR 68 Subpart B.  The Hazard Assessment includes the following:

Worst-case release scenario analysis
Alternative release scenario analysis
Off-site population impacts
Off-site environmental impacts
Five-year accident history

The first four (4) criteria are addressed in this Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) section.  The Five-Year Accident History is addressed in the following section.

Results of the OCA are necessary to accomplish the following:

Select the applicable RMP Prevention Program (1, 2, or 3) for each process
Meet the Hazard Assessment requirements for processes in each program

Kinder Morgan Delta Terminal (Delta) is required to develop an RMP for the facility due to the presence toluene 2, 4 diisocyanate (TDI) in excess of the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs for a regulated substance listed in 40 CFR 68.130. 

Facility Operations

Delta stores toluene-2,4 diisocyanate in three (3) aboveground fixed-roof storage tanks.  The material is brought to the terminal on a contract basis primarily via rail, but delivered or shipped via barge and truck.  The largest storage tank at the facility, 300-1, having a storage capacity of 1,100,000 gallons of toluene-2,4 diisocyanate.  There are also two (2) smaller volume tanks, 120-2 and 80-2 at the facility for this product service.  In addition to the stationary sources, there are drumming and rail car operations occurring at the site that has the potential to contain up to 5,800 (55 gal) drums and at minimum one (1) full rail car of TDI.  A total of five (5) rail cars on-site is assumed for maximum inventory calcul

26907 LDEQ Facility ID Number


Risk Management Planning (RMP) regulations are governed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) to require facilities already under OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) to develop and submit a formal risk management plan to assess the potential impacts of an accidental chemical release.  The RMP rule is divided into three programs, based on off-site chemical impacts of neighboring schools, residential areas, and other structures of public occupation.  Programs 1 and 2 apply to facilities that pose no or limited risk to the off-site receptors while Program 3 requires additional requirements to effectively monitor and create response controls.  Triggers for these programs exist based on risk, population density, SIC code, five-year accident history, PSM applicability, and if the facility exceeds threshold quantities of listed chemicals.  Facilities that maintain inventories of regulated chemicals in excess of threshold quantities, as defined in 40 CFR 68.130, are required to develop a Risk Management Plan and submit to the USEPA, as well as state and local agencies.

Kinder Morgan Delta Terminal Services operates a bulk liquid storage terminal in Harvey, Louisiana.  Delta Terminal Services stores a variety of chemicals ranging from coconut oil to volatile organic substances.  

This facility is regulated under Program 2 rule requirements under 68.10 because:

It maintains storage inventories of Toluene 2, 4-diisocyanate, a listed toxic chemical, in excess of 10,000 lbs as defined by 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart G
   A release from the Kinder Morgan Delta Terminal could impact an off-site receptor (e.g. Residence, schools, etc.)
   It does not operate under a SIC code specified for program 3 rule
   It is not subject to OSHA PSM because PSM does not apply to flammable l

ations  

Transfer pumps are used in the product transferring process between the storage tanks and the drumming facility.  The drums are filled and sealed to be loaded onto van trailers for transport.  The amount of TDI stored in storage tanks and at other stationary sources in the facility exceeds the RMP threshold of 10,000 pounds.

The maximum quantity of TDI in the largest tank, 300-1, is 11,500,000 pounds.  The maximum is intended inventory is 21,300,000 lbs. 

Modeling

RMP*Comp¿, a modeling program developed by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), was utilized to perform the OCA calculations required under the RMP regulation.  The primary result is the calculation of a distance (in miles) to an endpoint for each release scenario.  The distance to an endpoint is the distance a fire or explosion, from the point of an accidental release, will travel before dissipating to the point that serious injuries from short-term exposures will no longer occur.  Endpoints are defined in 40 CFR 68.22. 

A second aspect of the modeling is to determine if off-site receptors are located within the distance endpoint.  Landview 6, a mapping system that includes database extracts from the EPA, the Bureau of Census, the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), and other federal agencies was utilized.  Additionally, USGS topographic maps were reviewed to identify potential environmental receptors as required in 40 CFR 68.33.

Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis

RMP development requires the completion of a Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis.  In order to maintain consistency from facility to facility, 40 CFR Part 68.25 defines various parameters needed to conduct a worst-case release analysis.  The probability of an actual worst-case release is not a factor in this scenario.

Worst-case release scenario modeling assumptions used are predetermined by the regulations and include the following:

Complete failure of t

ems may be included in alternative release scenarios to ensure the accuracy of the evaluation.

The following release scenarios were considered in association with the storage and handling of bulk liquid transfer and storage at the facility:

Pump or valve housing or seal failures
Hard piping or storage tank leaks or failures
Storage tank relief valve failures
Storage tank overfilling

The alternative release scenario, selected by Delta personnel for evaluation, involves the failure and/or release from hose connections and process valving at transfer points.  The flexible transfer hose has a nominal inside diameter of 2-inches.  The rate of the transfer pump is 300 gallon/minute.  

RMP*Comp¿ calculated the release rate of TDI through a 2-inch opening as 0.176 pounds/minute.  This scenario was modeled using a release duration of one (1) minute, based on an estimate to allow facility personnel to identify the failure and to implement actions to stop the release.  At this rate, 3,052 pounds of TDI would be released.  RMP*Comp¿ modeled the distance endpoint for the release of 3,052 pounds of TDI as 0.1-mile.  The hazard endpoint 0.1 does not extend offsite.  

Conclusion

A worst-case release of 11,500,000 pounds of TDI from the facility may affect up to 365 persons within 0.3 miles from the tanks or dike.  A reasonable TDI alternative release scenario is the failure and/or release from hose connections and process valving at transfer points.  Under this scenario, 3,052 pounds of TDI would be released.  The resultant release does not extend offsite.
